Detailed Description

Specialized page for preloading environment setting before the package be launched.

Base class for those who need to maintain global application state. You can provide your own implementation by specifying its name in your AndroidManifest.xml's <application> tag, which will cause that class to be instantiated for you when the process for your application/package is created.

There is normally no need to subclass PersistentPage. In most situation, static singletons can provide the same functionality in a more modular way.

Warning:
In order to activate PersistentPage, remember to specify the android:name and android:persistent attributes in <application> tag in AndroidManifest.xml.

The sample code for PersistentPage is as follows. 

 // header file
 #include <gaia/core/PersistentPage.h>
 class PersistentPageTest : public gaia::core::PersistentPage {
 public:
     PersistentPageTest();
     virtual ~PersistentPageTest();
     virtual void onCreate();
 };
 
 // Implementation file
 #include "PersistentPageTest.h"
 PersistentPageTest::PersistentPageTest() {
     // Do something
 }
 
 PersistentPageTest::~PersistentPageTest() {
     // Do something.
 }
 
 void PersistentPageTest::onCreate() {
     // Do something.
 }

virtual void gaia::core::PersistentPage::onConfigurationChanged ( content::Configuration *  newConfig) [protected, virtual]

Called by the system when the device configuration changes while your component is running.

Note that, unlike Pages, other components are never restarted when a configuration changes: they must always deal with the results of the change, such as by re-retrieving resources. At the time that this function has been called, your Resources object will have been updated to return resource values matching the new configuration.

Parameters:
newConfigThe new device configuration.
virtual void gaia::core::PersistentPage::onCreate ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called when the application is starting, before any other application objects have been created.

Implementations should be as quick as possible (for example using lazy initialization of state) since the time spent in this function directly impacts the performance of starting the first activity, service, or receiver in a process.

virtual void gaia::core::PersistentPage::onTerminate ( ) [protected, virtual]

This method is for use in emulated process environments.

It will never be called on a production Android device, where processes are removed by simply killing them; no user code (including this callback) is executed when doing so.

void gaia::core::PersistentPage::setApplicationProxy ( ApplicationProxy *  appProxy) [protected]
